snippet: A study published in The Lancet, a British science journal, suggests the maternal mortality rate could drop by a full third if all needs for family planning were met.
abstract: Study by researchers at Johns Hopkins University and published in The Lancet shows that fulfilling unmet contraception demand by women in developing countries could reduce global maternal mortality by nearly a third, a potentially great improvement for one of the world’s most vulnerable populations; study comes ahead of a major family planning conference in London organized by the British government and the Bill and Melinda Gates Foundation.
lead_paragraph: A study published in The Lancet, a British science journal, suggests the maternal mortality rate could drop by a full third if all needs for family planning were met.

headline.seo: Meeting Contraception Needs Could Sink Maternal Death Rate
headline.main: Study Says Meeting Contraception Needs Could Cut Maternal Deaths by a Third
headline.print_headline: Study Says Meeting Contraception Needs Could Cut Maternal Death Rate by a Third
